awd_titl_txt: EAGER: A Novel Bioprocess for the Valorization of Waste and Biomass
awd_abstract_narration:
1600075
Mathews

The move to transition to a sustainable society will require a paradigm shift in waste management. The treatment and disposal of high-strength organic wastes involves high capital and operating cost expenditures. This project focuses on the valorization of biomass wastes to useful chemicals using a novel low pH microbial fermentation process that affords efficient extraction of the products. The extracted products will provide low-cost biodegradable deicers for applications on roads, highways, and airports for snow and ice control. This benefits include avoidance of waste treatment costs, the generation of value-added products, and the elimination of water and soil pollution from currently used chloride deicers.

Considerable amount of energy and resources are expended in aerobic and anaerobic treatment of wastes at present. The only chemical that is currently produced at large scale from organic wastes is methane gas, a low-value commodity chemical that is in excess supply. It is produced by anaerobic process that is costly and complex to operate. This project is aimed at developing a two-stage fermentation process for the conversion of biomass wastes to calcium magnesium acetate and propylene glycol. The EAGER project will develop microbial growth kinetics data and continuous immobilized cell fermentation data for the conversion lactic acid to acetic acid at low pH values where product extraction is most efficient. Novel porous supports will be used for cell immobilization. Extraction studies will be conducted at low pH values for acetic acid extraction. This project will develop new knowledge in the area of low pH bioconversion, advance knowledge in the area of immobilized cell fermentation, and advance knowledge in the area of acid extraction from fermentation liquor at low pH values. This project is transformative as it can engender research into the valorization of many different organic wastes and biomass to useful products. This project will have significant social, economic, and environmental impacts. The proposed project will enable the generation of high-value chemicals that will provide economic benefits to society. The capital and operating costs associated with the treatment of oxygen-demanding wastes will be eliminated. Moreover, the biodegradable deicers that are produced will replace non-biodegradable deicers such as sodium and calcium chlorides that are currently used for road and airport runway deicing. Large-scale application of inorganic salts to deice roads and highways has caused sodium and chloride contamination of surface waters, ground waters, and soils. Society will benefit from the health and aesthetic advantages associated with a cleaner environment and a healthy ecosystem from the use of biodegradable deicers. In addition, these new deicer products will prevent costs associated with automobile corrosion and costs related to rehabilitation of buildings and civil infrastructure that are damaged by application of conventional deicing chloride salts.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Innovations at the Nexus of Food-Energy-
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Overview: The world is currently operating in a “take-make-waste” mode, the so called linear economy, wherein materials are extracted, products are produced, and wastes are discarded. This mode of operation results in significant environmental pollution including the generation of greenhouse gases that contribute to climate change and associated problems. The move to transition to a sustainable society will require a paradigm shift in the approach to the management of wastes. This project focuses on the valorization of biomass wastes to useful chemicals such as acetic acid and propylene glycol, using a novel microbial fermentation process that affords efficient extraction of the products. The acetic acid obtained will provide for a low-cost route for the production of biodegradable acetate deicers for application on roads, highways, and airports for snow and ice control in winter. Propylene glycol is also commonly used for aircraft deicing. This will have benefits from avoidance of waste treatment costs, the generation of value-added products, and the elimination of water and soil pollution from currently used chloride deicers.

Intellectual Merit:  The goal of this project was to investigate a novel microbial fermentation process for the conversion of biomass wastes to valuable products, acetic acid, propylene glycol, and calcium magnesium acetate deicer. The EAGER project developed microbial growth kinetics data and continuous immobilized cell fermentation data for the conversion of whey lactose, and xylose to acetic acid at low pH values where product extraction is most efficient. Novel supports were studied for cell immobilization to enhance productivity. Extraction studies were conducted at low pH values using ion exchange resins and activated carbon. This project developed new knowledge in the area of bioconversion of xylose and lactose under acidic conditions, and has advanced the knowledge base in the areas of immobilized cell fermentation, and acid extraction under acidic conditions. This project is transformative as it can engender research into the valorization of many different organic wastes and agricultural raw materials to useful products.

Broader Impacts: This project will have significant social, economic, and environmental impacts. Considerable amount of energy and resources are expended in aerobic and/or anaerobic treatment of wastes at present. The only chemical that is currently produced from organic wastes is methane gas, a low-value commodity chemical that is in excess supply. Methane is produced by an anaerobic process that is costly and complex to operate. This method of processing is not economical to enable its use to move towards a circular economy. The proposed project will enable the generation of high-value chemicals that will provide economic benefits to society. The capital and operating costs associated with the treatment of oxygen demanding wastes will be eliminated. Moreover, the biodegradable deicers that are produced will replace non-biodegradable deicers such as sodium and calcium chlorides that are currently being used for road and airport runway deicing.  Large-scale application of chloride salts to deice roads and highways has caused sodium and chloride contamination of surface and ground waters, and soils. Society will benefit from the health and aesthetic benefits associated with a cleaner environment and a healthy ecosystem from the use of biodegradable deicers. Also, society will benefit from the avoidance of costs associated with corrosion of automobiles, and costs related to rehabilitation of buildings and civil infrastructure from corrosion due to the application of chloride salts for deicing.

Project Outcomes: A bioconversion process that operates effectively under acidic conditions was developed for the first time for the utilization of biomass wastes to produce biochemicals such as acetic acid, propylene glycol, and lactic acid. This anoxic process is cost effective compared to anaerobic processes that require the maintenance of thermophilic temperatures and strict anaerobic conditions. In the bioconversion of biomass and wastes to useful chemicals, the downstream separation and purification costs represent the highest percentage of the total production cost. The fermentation process developed herein will minimize downstream costs due to the high extraction efficiency for organic acids under acidic conditions. Kinetic data for bioconversion were developed from batch fermentation studies and used in a mathematical model to predict the performance continuous fermentation systems. The model can be used in the design and operation of pilot scale systems for testing the potential of this process with different wastes for full-scale applications.

One graduate student, and one undergraduate student, and one postdoctoral research associate were mentored and trained in the conduct of research and dissemination of results. Project results have been disseminated through four peer-reviewed publications in professional journals.

 


Last Modified: 04/18/2019
Modified by: Alexander P Mathews
